Saleebys 2nd Report on Dengue
note p9 re Lazear's help

Columbia Barracks, Havana, Cuba,
June 6th, 1900.
THE FEVER THAT WAS EPIDEMIC IN THIS POST LAST FALL.

Cases of the fever that was epidemic in this post from the mid-
dle of September to the middle of November, 1899, kept straggling in
all the latter part of November. Several cases occurred in December
and January. One officer was attacked on the second day after his
arrival here. His fever reached 103.4° F. on the first day of the
disease, then descended gradually to normal, lasting a little over
five days. About half a dozen cases were observed in February and
March. Two of themwere boys, both nine years old. In all these cases
the blood was examined by Dr. J. W. Lazear, and the result was in-
variably negative for Malaria. The urine presented no albumen. Dr.
Lazear observed a few cases of fever in which the temperature drop-
ped down to normal either on the first or second day after admission
into the hospital, and in which he could not find the plasmodium
malariae; but as I did not observe them I could not identify them
with the fever under consideration. All the cases I include in the
above occurred in the 8th Infantry Barracks, ran a course of more
than three days, and are unaccounted for by any other cause except the
specific cause of the fever under consideration, which they seem to
identify.

Chart III,No.1, represents the only case I observed in April.
The patient is an officer who contracted the disease at the termi-
nation of a trip around the Island of Cuba, on board the Transport
“Ingalls.” During that trip he visited Santiago and Cienfuegos on
his way back. Previous to the trip, I treated him for a mild sub-
chronic pharyngitis on several occasions. He had sore throat during
the trip. The tout--ensemble of his symptoms resembled that of the
fever under consideration. The first temperature registered in the
chart was taken at 1:00 P.M., about two hours after his arrival home.
The headache was severe but the rachialgia was very mild. His sore
throat increased. The mucous membrane of the pharynx fauces and soft
(2)
palate was red and swollen. The body of the tonsils was not enlarged,
there was no soreness felt on the outside, but swallowing was pain-
ful. This soreness passed away on April 3rd, though the redness and
congestion of the mucous membrane waswere still noticeable on the 6th. He h
had nose bleed and vomited several times on both April 1st and 2nd.
The temperature dropped down one degree April 3rd, and all the sym-
ptoms improved. His temperature reached normal on the 4th. At about
1:00 A.M. that day, he had critical perspiration, had three “weak
spells” as he expressed it, changed his clothes three times during
the night, and felt extremely weak. The picture of a systemic infec-
tion; well defined course of fever ending in crisis; anaamia, sub-
normal temperature, and unusual weakness during convalescense; and
the unusually slow pulse, are characteristic features of this case.
The blood was examined carefully for malaria and gave a negative
result. The urine was examined four successive mornings and never
presented any albumen. Both urine and blood were examined by Dr.
Lazear.

The general character presented by all these cases areI hereby
referred to, seems to me to be exactly the same as that of the fever
of last fall. The rachialgia that was intense in the earlier part
of the epidemic diminished considerably towards its end, and was so
mild after that that it did not attract much attention. The major-
ity had one single paroxysm of fever, but few presented that char-
acteristic second or “reactionary” rise of the temperature that was
termed a second paroxysm in the previous report.

All of these cases are primary attacks. None presented an
eruption, none suggested dengue. It is a noteworthy fact that none
of the ladies of the post contracted the disease.

Through the kindness of Dr. H. R. Carter, Surgeon, U. S. H. M.S.
I am able to present a copy of the charts of six of the severest
cases of a fever which occurred on board the U. S. T. S. “Lancaster”
at the southern coast of Cuba, during the month of February. Dr. J.D.
Gatewood, Surgeon, U. S. N., the medical officer in command, con-
sidered them to be yellow fever cases and transferred them to the
(3)
charge of the U.S.M.H.S. at Cienfuegos for isolation purposes. The
temperature line the charts present is very similar to that of my
charts and shows very clearly the rapid rise, the characteristic
descending line, the brief intermission, and the secondary rise of
a “reactionary fever,” The lack of correlation between pulse and tem-
perature is marked, and the severest two cases presented albumin in
the urine. Only these two cases when viewed separately were pronoun-
ced “suspicious cases” of yellow fever by the U.S.M.H.S. Surgeons
but on the whole the diagnosis of yellow fever was not corroborated.

, A heavy rain fall at the beginning of May declared the advent
of the rainy season. It rained the greater part of the month, chief-
ly during the first three weeks.

The first yellow fever case that occurred in this post
made its appearance on the 24th of May. This was a “genuine” case
and is represented by No. 2, Chart IV. The patient did not have the
fever of last fall. No. IV of the same chart is a case of mild
yellow fever in an American girl, eleven years old, who lived in the
neighboring village of Quemados, and whose father died of the same
disease on May 31st. Her mother and another person contracted the
disease in the same house. Her symptoms were very mild, she had no
jaundice, and her urine presented no albumen. The Cuban doctors
who saw her diagnosised the case “infectious fever”. These two
cases are mentioned here simply for comparison.

No. III, Chart IV represents the case of an old soldier who took ill
on the 27th of May and who was not ill during the epidemic of last
fall. He had fever all day and did not apply for treatment until
3:00 P.M. He looked very ill then, the face was flushed and tremu-
lous, the eyes suffused and red, moderate congestion extended down
the neck to the shoulders. The headache was superaorbital and was the
severest symptom. The rachialgia was very mild, anorexia, consti-
pation, no abdominal tenderness. The blood was carefully examined by
Dr. Lazear for malaria with a negative result. The urine was acid
and showed no albumen on the second day. Some albumen with few pus
cells appeared on the third and fourth days. He had no symptoms of
(4)
of eystitis and his fever lasted more than two days. There was no
cause to account for his illness except this specific fever. His
pulse dropped in the evening of the second day from 96 to 64 while
the temperature rose from 100° to 101°. Had it been possible to ex-
amine the urine of all the cases of the epidemic of last fall as
carefully as at present, I have reason to believe that a number of
them would have presented some albumen in the urine during the lat-
ter part of the disease.

No. I, Chart IV is the case of an American civilian who lived
at Quemados and had severer symptoms than the preceding case, and had
no albuminuria. No plasmodiae were found in the blood.

In the course of my inquiry about the cases of fever at Santi-
ago during the late campaign of 1898, I learned from a number of
sources that there were characteristic cases of a fever that are best
expressed by the words of Major Gorgas, Surgeon, U.S.A., “that
they were not yellow fever; no one considered them dengue; most con-
sidered them malarial; that the mortality was almost nil, and that
there were a number of deaths from yellow fever.”

Dr. C. Hamilton Tebault, Jr., of New Orleans, La., who was
assigned to the Officers Hospital at Santiago, Cuba, referring to the
same subject, describes a type of fever which he calls “Calentura”,
adopting the common Cuban word for fever. “Calenthura”, he said,
“is a fever of one paroxysm. There usually is an initial chill
which generally takes place in the morning, or late at night. The
chill may be absent and only chilly sensations felt over the body.
The temperature as a rule starts at a higher degree than one would
look for in mild yellow fever. The pulse is often slow from the
start, and falls steadily. It remains slow for a longer period than
in mild yellow fever. There may be jaundice but this is unusual. If
we pay attention to the headache, capillary stasis and calf pains,
we are apt to be mislead.”

“The fever falls on the fourth or fifth day in severe cases,
but in mild cases it disappears on the second day. I have never seen
anything like secondary infection in this disease corresponding to
(5)
Sanarelli's per iod of secondary infection of yellow fever.”
“There may be vomiting at the outset, but this is usually gone by
the second day.”

“The urine, though often scanty, contains no albumen, or at
least contains only a trace when the fever began at a very high de-
gree.” “The mortality from Calentura at the Military Hospital
and at the officers hospital was nil.”

“That it is a specific disease of microbic origin is beyond
question. It is non-contagious. Certain atmospheric conditions favor
its rapid spread.”

The above quotations show plainly that Dr. Teabault recognized
a type of fever similar to the one under consideration. His views
and statements concerning its relation to yellow fever and malaria
seem to be uncertain and contradict each other. This I attribute to
the fact that cases of malaria, calentura, and “genuine” yellow
fever existed side by side all the time. His composite chart, No 2, Chart III
represents the type of the fever.
CONCLUSIONS.

General Character. In summing up the results of my observations
on the subject, I find that we have to deal with an acute infectious
fever that is endemic in this island. It occurs sporadically all the
year around, and assumes epidemic proportions on favorable occasions.
It is a non-contagious disease whose infectious agent seems to depend
for its development upon certain atmospheric and telluric conditions.
A certain degree of temperature and humidity favors its growth,
while cold weather and storm ret ard it at least. The disease starts
from an infected lacality and extends from that as a centre, appar-
ently by soil cantiguity. Isolation of the sick in hospital did not
seem to effect its spread. The epidemic seemed to start inside the
limits of the camp, was restricted to foreigners and did not spread
as such outside camp limits. There had not been any epidemic of any
kind either in Havana or in this vicinity.

Three of the officers' children contracted the disease, two
boys and one girl, all about nine years old. None of the ladies in
(6)
camp had it. The mortality of the epidemic was nil.

Symptomatology. The incubation period varied between one day
and two weeks. The duration of the disease varied from sixty hours
to eight days. The greater number of the cases pre sented one paroxysm,
the minority two. The second paroxysm whenever it occurred formed
practically a continuous course with the first, was only separated
by a brief intermission, and resembled very closely what is called
the “reactionary fever”, or the “second infection” of yellow fever,
thus giving rise to what might be termed a xxxxxxxxxxxxxx third stage
of the disease.

The onset was always sudden. “The acme of the temperature was
reached at the outset (within thirty-six hours) and from this time
the temperature line was a descending one”. The termination was of
course by lysis. There were twenty relapses in about 350 cases.

The first stage was always marked by distinct capillary conges-
tion of the skin and the mucous membrahne; especially the face, neck,
eyes, and throat, but there were no hemorrhages either primary or
secondary. The cephalalgia and rachialgia were severe and seemed to
hang on with unusual tenacity, especially the latter. The gastric dis-
turbances were mild. The pulse was markedlyy slow and often lacked
correlation with the temperature. The urine was highly acid, dimin-
ished in amount, but as a rule contained no albumen. The skin kept
generally dry and presented neither icterus nor any characteristic
eruption. The joints were not affected at all. There were cerebral un-
easiness and marked systemic disturbance, the patients looked as well
as they would be in the first two days of either typhoid or yellow
fever.

Differential Diagnosis. Malaria. In view of our present knowl-
edgw of malaria and in light of the aforesaid facts there is certainly
no re ason to believe that this disease “is one of the many turns
malaria takes.” This idea is a legend of the past.

Dengue. Dengue was discussed early during the first part of the
epidemic and was given up. Later it was resumed by another party,
but I am not aware of the occurrence of any case that was so diag-
nosed since last December. It was the severity and unusual tenac-
(7)
cety of the rachialgia together with the benignity of the disease
and the occasional occurrence of uncharacteristic eruptions that led
to the proclamation of this diagnosis.

But in face of the facts that the diseaze started in camp, was trace-
able to an infected laocality from which it spread out, as aforesaid,
was restricted to foreigners, and did not spread outside the limit
of our camp; and in view of the facts that there was not at the same
time either dengue or any other epidemic disease either in Havana
or in our vicinity, or on the Island that I am aware of; and in view
of the facts that no ladies in camp contracted the disease; that the
joints were not affected at all, that there was no characteristic
erupption (a symptom that I did carefully investigate); in face of
all that I feel that I cannot [unclear] refrain from refuting this diagnosis.

Calentura and Yellow Fever. Calentura may be what the Cubans
call “infectious Fever”. The adoption of the term calentura that some
have suggested means the recognition of a disease that is unsatis-
factorily described as yet, and whose relations and differential di-
agnosis from yellow fever are not yet established. This is a diffi-
cult problem for whose solution we must wait for future developments
and observations. And we have already plain indications that such de-
velopments may soon appear and help to dispel certain clouds of un-
certainty that seem to hang over this vexed question. It is therefore
proper to reserve the decision to the future, and simply point out
at present the several points where in this disease simulates or dif-
fers from yellow fever as we know it.

It would certainly seem ridiculous to state before the profes-
sion that we have had an epidemic of yellow fever without any mor-
tality, icterus, hhaemorrhages, or a sign of a haemorrhaagex, and that
as a rule there was not any amount of albumen in the urine that is
worth mentioning. Yet it is a fact that some physicians who had con-
siderable experience with yellow fever have declared to me that the
epidemic was yellow fever in spite of all that. In their opinion Cal-
entura would simply be very mild yellow fever and persons attacked
with it obtain immunity from the latter disease.

Uninfluenced by any opinion except the facts that are before
(8)
me, I can not overestimate the evidence that the course of the fever
bears. The variations of the temperature are not always given the con-
sideration they should be credited with. The charts show very vividly
that the life - cycle of the germ of this disease is very similar
indeed to that of yellow fever. The period of incubation, invasion,
acme, decline, intermission, and secondary rise are not only indi-
cated but simulate and correspond with those of yellow fever very
closely. The secondary rise of the fever is a characteristic clinical
peculiarity of yellow fever, that La Roche states is “of itself al-
most sufficient to enable us to diagnosis the case.” It certainly
speaks of an undoubted similarity between the causecourse of the two fevers.

The rise of the epidemic, the localization of the infection,
its endemicity, its spread, its restriction to strangers, the ex-
emption of the female sex, the influence of atmospheric and telluric
conditions upon its progress, all are very indicative. It is not nec-
essary to say that all the subjective and objective symptoms mentioned
in the former report could be easily interpreted by yellow fever
and that any deviation from the genral character could be easily ex-
plained as a peculiarity of the individual epidemic. I cannot pass
on without remarking on the resemblance between the symptoms of the
mild yellow fever of Jamaica as described by I. Anderson and those of
the symptoms of this disease.

The cutaneous and mucous membrane congestions were marked, that
of the throat being very mild, and no hemorrhages occurred. The pulse
was slow out of all proportion to the temperature and veryhoften
presented marked lack of correlation with the latter though not to
the same extent as in severe yellow fever.

But here the relation stops, the infection does not seem to
cause any marked internal congestion or tissue degeneration, con-
sequently we do not find either the expected amount of albumen in
the urine, or icterus, or passive hemmorrhage; neither is there any
real collapse or prolonged prostration.

The life history of the germs certainly simulate each other close-
ly, but their toxicities differ considerably. Now do the toxines
differ in kind or in degree? Is the degree of toxicity proportional
(9)
to the rise of the temperature? Can the same toxine that determines
the rise of the temperature and the degree of toxicity lose one qual-pro-
ityperty and maintain the other?

The poison of yellow fever seems to undergo considerable atten-
uation in children. Some writers speak of having treated one hundred
and even two hundred cases of yellow fever in children without a sin-
gle death; but even then there is albumen in the urine as a rule and
occasional icterus and passive hemorrhages from the mucous membranes.
It is generally conceded that the epidemics that occur later in the year
especially those that come in the fall are mild and have a low mor-
tality. But I do not know whether any epidemic of yellow fever has
ever been reported with no mortality. Still it should not be forgot-
ten that we are encamped on the crest of a hill one of the most sa-
lubrious spots on the Island. The hill is of limestone rock and the
soil has no depth to it, and has not been tilled. The place is iso-
lated from the city and was not inhabited before. All our buildings
are of wood and new, our hygenic surroundings are practically perfect.
The men are weell disciplined, the sewer system is complete, and the
kitchens and dining rooms are kept scrupulously clean.

It would be of considerable interest to study in this light yel-
low fever cases as they appear this summer, and watch to see whether
the men that were attacked last fall have obtained any immunity from
yellow fever or not. No matter what decision shall be arrived at
concerning this disease, it is bound to add some light to our present
knowledge of yellow fever, acclimation and acquired immunity from it,
and the relation of yellow fever to both dengue and calenthura if
the latter be confirmed.

I feel greatly indebted to Dr. H. R. Carter, Surgeon, U.S.M.H.S.,
for many valuable lessons and suggestions, and for the great interest
he took in repeated discussions on the subject in hand. In apprecia-
tion of all that and with full respect to his ideas and opinion I
hereby present his letter in toto. I also feel very thankful to Dr.
J. W. Lazear, A.A. Surgeon, U.S.A., for his valuable aid and pro-
fessional help.
